awd_abstract_narration: This is a moderate RAPID award for the researcher to excavate a feature at an archaeological site that is potentially culturally significant and in danger of being destroyed.

por.por_cntn:
This research involved excavation at the Upward Sun River site and was designed to accomplish two objectives (1) to excavate and record an ancient burial/cremation in its entirety to understand the human remains, the earliest found in northern North America, and (2) to explore the association of the burial feature with the main excavation area to identify associated cultural remains recovered during prior excavations. Four occupations are known from the site (from 13,300 to 10,000 years ago), and it was uncertain which one is associated with the burial.

 

In summer, 2010, we discovered ancient human remains, designated ‘Xaa Saa Cheeg’e Ts’eniin (or Upward Sun River Mouth Child) by local Native Athabaskans, in the Tanana basin, central Alaska. At present, no burials have been found in Ice Age contexts Northwest North America, so our knowledge of an entire suite of mortuary-related behaviors is essentially unknown. Following our legal agreements with local and regional Native Americans, the NSF, and the State of Alaska, we left the remains untouched in the field upon discovery and continued consultation. With unanimous support from all parties, we proposed to excavate the burial feature. This project contributed transformative data to our understanding of this time period in the Western Hemisphere, and has the potential to inform current debates about health, diet, and genetic affiliation of ancient North Americans.

 

Analyses are ongoing, but all of the research objectives have been met, and the initial findings include the following. The burial was completely excavated, and was found to be associated with a pit-hearth within a residential structure (the earliest of its kind in the Arctic/Subarctic). Mortuary analyses indicate the child was cremated and buried in the pit, and the house was subsequently abandoned. Bioanthropological analyses indicate the child died at ~3 years of age, laid on his/her back within the pit, and cremated. Dental traits are suggestive of a Sinodont pattern characteristic of Northeast Asians and Native Americans. The burial and house feature are directly associated (through radiocarbon dating and stratigraphy) with Component 3, dating to around ~11,500 years ago.

 

Faunal remains associated with the pit hearth are very well preserved, indicating diets of fish (salmonids), ground squirrel, snowshoe hare, marmot, ptarmigan/grouse, and other avians. This suite of animals is unprecedented for the region, and allows for a fuller understanding of ancient lifeways. The presence of salmonids and immature ground squirrels indicate a summer season of occupation.

 

Stone tool analyses at this residential site contrast with typical hunting sites in the region, and support the interpretation of a single broad Late Pleistocene (Ice Age) cultural tradition with variation based on habitat use, seasonality, and mobility patterns. There are some similarities of these mortuary, residential, stone tool, and subsistence patterns with Ushki 1 Level 6 and the Diuktai Culture of Northeast Asia.

 

This project made direct impacts on a PhD student’s research project. He continued directing the geoarchaeological component of the research. Both graduate and undergraduate students aided in the excavation and garnered experience working with a complex Subarctic site.

 

We continued our outreach with respect to the local and regional Native populations. We continued our negotiations on the legal document under which this project operated. We had a site visit from the local Native chief and her family. We arranged a visit by the local tribal members to our laboratory to view the specimens and ask questions about the work. We prepared and published a Science article which was widely reported on in domestic and international outlets. The original press release included television and radio coverage, and included the PI (Potter), bioanthropologist (Irish), local Native Chief (Polston), and regional Native non-profit group (Isaac). Since the press release and publication, this research has been of general interest to regional, national, and international media and the American public.

 

This research has positive impacts at a variety of levels, including informing current debates on paleo-health, diet, possibly genetic affiliation of an early American, as well as broader questions about ancient subsistence and economies and debates about Late Pleistocene colonization of the Western Hemisphere. This research provides new empirical data relevant to a wide range of scientific interests, including archaeology, physical anthropology, geology, and paleoecology. This research contributes to our understanding of human response to climate change by providing valuable new data on the human component of past subarctic systems at a critical point in time (early human colonization and the transition from the Last Ice Age to the present interglacial).
